characters: LEON AND NINOTCHKA, DANCING A WALTZ
LIVING ROOM OF THE ROYAL SUITE
ALL THREE SITTING AT THE TABLE
LIVING ROOM OF A VERY LUXURIOUS HOTEL SUITE IN CONSTANTIN

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: shooting toward door of elevator. The elevator comes up a stops, the door opens, and the Three Russians step out. T are very smartly dressed and look like any urbane gentlem coming from the races. Two of them have racing glasses. A they walk toward the Royal Suite, Lady Lavenham, an elder English aristocrat, comes out of her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, messieurs, mes  Comrades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Lady Lavenham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how is Lord Lavenham?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and little Lady Beatrice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. Did fortune favor you at  the races?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comme ci, comme ca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand... nothing to write  home about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Who wants to write home about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a saying. How about joining  us Saturday night for dinner? We're  having a few friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we free, Buljanoff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll manage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's say at nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black tie or white tie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, let's make it white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Au revoir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Au revoir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk into the Royal Suite, Buljanoff tosses off a urbane comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice people.

dialogues.speaker: ANTEROOM OF ROYAL SUITE
dialogues.text: As the three enter, the telephone rings. Buljanoff and  Kopalski go into the living room. Iranoff answers the  telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into telephone) Yes, Leon... (a little bit annoyed) What is it, Leon?... You can't hurry  such things... You must give Moscow  a little time... There's nothing we  can do about it... why don't you  drop in later?... Au revoir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: As Iranoff enters Buljanoff rushes toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Misha! Misha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A telegram from Moscow! It must have  been here all day!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joining them and  reading telegram) Halt negotiations immediately. Envoy  extraordinary arrives Thursday six  ten with full power. Your authority  cancelled herewith. Razinin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Thursday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's six o'clock already!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rush into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always said it would be Siberia!

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY
dialogues.text: Manager at desk. Iranoff, Buljanoff, and Kopalski rush fr the direction of the elevator. Iranoff pauses at the desk The others go on to the door and wait for him there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Manager) A Special Envoy is coming from Moscow.  He'll occupy the Royal Suite. Move  our things to the smallest room you've  got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right away... instantly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the door Buljanoff and Kopalski call impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iranoff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he starts toward the door, we

dialogues.speaker: PLATFORM
dialogues.text: The train has already arrived as the Three Russians hurry down the platform. Neither do they know the name of the E Extraordinary, nor his appearance, and they are searching the crowd for some clue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a fine thing. Maybe we've  missed him already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you find somebody without  knowing what he looks like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iranoff points to a bearded man with a knapsack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must be the one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he looks like a comrade!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They follow the man, but just as they are ready to approa him he is greeted by a German Girl. Both raise their hand in the Nazi salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the two embrace, the Three Russians stop in their trac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's not him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Positively not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now the platform is almost empty. As the Russians in t foreground look around helplessly, we see in the backgrou a woman who obviously is also looking for someone. It is  Ninotchka Yakushova, the Envoy Extraordinary. The Russian exchange troubled looks and go toward her. Ninotchka come forward. As they meet she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Iranoff) I am looking for Michael Simonovitch  Iranoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Michael Simonovitch Iranoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Nina Ivanovna Yakushova, Envoy  Extraordinary, acting under direct  orders of Comrade Commissar Razinin.  Present me to your colleagues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands. Ninotchka's grip is strong as a man's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comrade Buljanoff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comrade Kopalski...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a charming idea for Moscow to  surprise us with a lady comrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we had known we would have greeted  you with flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly) Don't make an issue of my womanhood.  We are here for work... all of us.  Let's not waste time. Shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Russians are taken aback. As Ninotchka bends down to  lift her two suitcases, Iranoff calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Porter steps up to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have your bags, madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is a porter. He wants to carry  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Porter) Why?... Why should you carry other  people's bags?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... that's my business, madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's no business... that's a social  injustice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends on the tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to take  Ninotchka's bags) Allow me, Comrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka takes both suitcases and walks away with the Th Russians, whose nervousness has increased with every word from the Envoy Extraordinary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are things in Moscow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. The last mass trials were  a great success. There are going to  be fewer but better Russians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hearts of the Three Russians drop to their boots, as

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY
dialogues.text: Ninotchka, followed by the Russians, comes through the lo observing every detail of these unfamiliar surroundings. Suddenly she stops. In the showcase of a hat shop in the  lobby is displayed a hat of the John-Frederic's type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hat, Comrade, a woman's hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tsk, tsk, tsk, how can such a  civilization survive which permits  women to put things like that on  their heads. It won't be long now,  Comrades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks out of the shot toward the elevator, followed b the Three Russians, as we

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL SUITE
dialogues.text: Ninotchka enters, followed by the Three Russians, who by are frightened to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the apartment we have reserved  for you, Comrade Yakushova. I hope  you like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing around the  tremendous room) Which part of the room is mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see... it is a little different  here. They don't rent rooms in pieces.  We had to take the whole suite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka begins to unpack her things and puts her typewr on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much does this cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two thousand francs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how much a cow costs,  Comrade Iranoff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two thousand francs. If I stay here  a week I will cost the Russian people  seven cows. (with an outburst of  emotion) Who am I to cost the Russian people  seven cows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had to take it on account of the  safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For ourselves... we are much happier  now since we moved to a little room  next to the servants' quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka takes Lenin's picture from her bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am ashamed to put the picture of  Lenin in a room like this. (she puts the  photograph on the  desk) Comrades, your telegram was received  with great disfavor in Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did our best, Comrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so for your sake. (she sits at her desk  and starts to type  her report) Let us examine the case. What does  the lawyer say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't get legal advice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't want to get mixed up with  lawyers. They are very expensive  here. If you just say hello to a  lawyer... well, there goes another  cow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We dealt directly with the  representative of the Grand Duchess.  I am sure if we call him he will  give you a very clear picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not repeat your mistake. I  will have no dealings with the Grand  Duchess nor her representative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka continues to type. The Three Russians watch her nervously. Each click pounds on their consciences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) Comrade Buljanoff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Comrade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you spell Buljanoff with one or  two f's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with fright in his  voice) With two f's, if you please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka goes on with her typing. Suddenly she looks up Iranoff, who becomes self-conscious and fixes his tie. As does so he sees that Ninotchka's glance is concentrated o the spats which he was wearing and in his hurry forgot to remove. He knows it is too late to do anything about it e to stand one foot behind the other, as Ninotchka types fa the clicking of her keys twice as loud. Ninotchka picks u the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Will you send me some cigarettes,  please? (suddenly getting up) Comrades, I am not in a position to  pass final judgment but at best you  have been careless in your duty to  the State. (with utmost gravity) You were entrusted with more than a  mere sale of jewelry. Why are we  peddling our precious possessions to  the world at this time? Our next  year's crop is in danger and you  know it. Unless we can get foreign  currency to buy tractors there will  not be enough bread for our people.  And you three comrades...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did it with the best intentions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cannot feed the Russian people on  your intentions. Fifty per cent to a  so-called Duchess!... Half of every  loaf of bread to our enemy! Comrade  Kopalski, go at once to our Embassy  and get the address of the best lawyer  in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Comrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Comrade Iranoff, go to the Public  Library and get me the section of  the Civil Code on property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can do, Comrade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might get me an accurate map of  Paris. I want to use my spare time  to inspect the public utilities and  make a study of all outstanding  technical achievements in the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Comrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The buzzer rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three Cigarette Girls enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaily) Hello! Hello! Cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka looks up astonished. Seeing her, the Cigarette  Girls freeze. The Russians stand by quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the  Russians) Comrades, you seem to have been  smoking a lot.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: shooting past the desk toward the revolving door. The  telephone rings and the Desk Clerk answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desk... yes, Monsieur Kopalski... (he writes down the  message) ...you are expecting Count d'Algout...  uh huh... but he is not to go to the  Royal Suite under any circumstances.  He should go to your new room, 985?  Thank you, monsieur. (he hangs up the  receiver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few seconds later Ninotchka, naturally completely unawa of the telephone conversation, passes by. She carries a m in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. She exits out the door.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR, HOTEL CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Ninotchka emerges, unfolds the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the hands of Ninotchka. The CAMERA ZOOMS down to a CLO UP of the little drawing of the Hotel Clarence on the map The CAMERA then PANS OVER from the Clarence toward the  opposite side of the street, but before we reach the oppo side we see that in the center of the street is a little  isle of safety. The CAMERA proceeds PANNING to the opposi side of the square and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Real Location Corresponding to That Seen on the Map a seen from the same ANGLE. It is evening, and along the st comes Leon on his way to the hotel. The CAMERA PANS with as he crosses the street. He reaches the isle of safety a there passes Ninotchka, who has come from the other side. They pass on the little isle without noticing each other. Suddenly we hear the whistle of a traffic policeman and b Ninotchka and Leon have to step back to the little isle.

dialogues.speaker: NINOTCHKA AND LEON
dialogues.text: on the little isle. Wanting some information Ninotchka tu to him -- completely impersonal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Could you give me some  information?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gladly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do we have to wait here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- until the policeman whistles  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At what intervals does he whistle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many minutes between the first  and second whistle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny. It's interesting. I  never gave it a thought before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you never been caught in a  similar situation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I? Do you know when I come to  think about it it's staggering. If I  add it all up I must have spent years  waiting for signals. Imagine! An  important part of my life wasted  between whistles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words you don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka gets out her map, starts to unfold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might hold this for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (engrossed in her  geography) Correct me if I am wrong... We are  facing north, aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) Facing north... I'd hate to commit  myself without my compass... Pardon  me... are you an explorer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I am looking for the Eiffel  Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that thing lost again?... Listen...  if you are interested in a view...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am interested in the Eiffel Tower  from a technical standpoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technical... I couldn't help you  from that angle. You see, a real  Parisian only goes to the top of the  tower in moments of despair to jump  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long does it take a man to land?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, isn't that too bad! The last  time I jumped I forgot to clock it! (looks at map) Let me see... Eiffel Tower... Your  finger, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her finger and points to the map with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptically) Why do you need my finger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad manners to point with your own...  Here... the Eiffel Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shifting her finger  back to the hotel) Here... here we are... here you are  and here I am... feel it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am interested only in the shortest  distance between these two points.  Must you flirt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to but I find it natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppress it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka starts to fold her map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For my own information would you  call your approach toward me typical  of the local morale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame, it is that kind of approach  which has made Paris what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are very sure of yourself, aren't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing has occurred recently to  shake my confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have heard of the arrogant male in  capitalistic society. It is having a  superior earning power that makes  you like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Russian! I love Russians! Comrade...  I have been fascinated by your Five- Year Plan for the past fifteen years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your type will soon be extinct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away from him coldly. Leon stares after her,  fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera moves with Ninotchka as she enters. She approaches Attendant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... can you tell me the exact  width of the foundation on which the  piers are resting?... and the depth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to worry. The thing  is safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not afraid... I want to know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon, who apparently has taken a taxi and prepared himsel otherwise, enters the scene, reading from a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) The foundation is one hundred and  forty-one yards square... (he tips his hat and  interjects) I hope you'll forgive me but I thought  you'd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA goes with Ninotchka and Leon as they walk towa the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Four massive piers of masonry are  sunk to a depth of forty-six feet on  the side of the Seine, and twenty- nine and one-half feet on the other  side. The girders of interlaced iron- work which stay the structure have  an inclination of fifty-four  degrees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a strange angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, very strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now they have reached the staircase. They start up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing to read) Ascending to the tower is a staircase  consisting of eight hundred and twenty- nine steps... (this disclosure  frightens Leon as he  realizes the climb  ahead of him. He  reads on as they  walk up) ...and an additional two hundred and  fifty-four steps to the very top... (now Leon stops but  Ninotchka proceeds  on out of the picture.  Leon calls after her  and reads from his  book in a loud voice) There is an elevator included in the  price of admission!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka continues to climb.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS, (FROM LEON'S ANGLE)
dialogues.text: Ninotchka, paying no attention to him, walks up the stair two at a time.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: He looks after Ninotchka, then makes up his mind and retu down the stairs. GROUND FLOOR -- EIFFEL TOWER, shooting toward the elevato door. The elevator with several passengers is just about leave when Leon hurries into it. The door closes and the  elevator starts to ascend quickly.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHEST PLATFORM
dialogues.text: The CAMERA ANGLE includes the elevator door and a beautif background view of Paris. The elevator door opens and Leo emerges leisurely. He is just about to step to the top of the staircase, when suddenly, to his great amazement, he  sees Ninotchka, who stands at the balustrade overlooking  Paris. She has climbed the tower faster than he despite t elevator. Dumbfounded, Leon approaches her. Ninotchka tur very matter-of-fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave me some very valuable  information. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the  dazzling view) And thank you for getting me up here.  I've never seen this before.  Beautiful, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad I saw it before becoming  extinct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not misunderstand me. I do not  hold your frivolity against you. (she looks him up and  down) As basic material you might not be  bad, but you are the unfortunate  product of a doomed culture. I feel  sorry for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must admit that this doomed old  civilization sparkles... It glitters!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night View of Paris with Its Lights Ablaze, as seen from Eiffel Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not deny its beauty, but it is  a waste of electricity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a city! There are the Grands  Boulevards... blasted out of the  heart of the old streets. The Arc de  Triomphe... made to greet Napoleon's  army. The Opera! And Montmartre...  Montparnasse... La BohГЁme... and now  I'll show you the greatest attraction! (he steps to a  telescope and, taking  some money from his  pocket, drops a coin  in the slot) It will cost me a franc but it is  worth it. (he adjusts the  telescope) The most wonderful spot in all Paris --  unique! Here, look.... (she looks in telescope) What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see a house that looks like any  other house. What's remarkable about  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the structure but the spirit  which dwells within. There are three  rooms and a kitchenette dedicated to  hospitality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that is your house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's say I live in it. Such a  pleasant place... all kinds of  comfort, easy to reach, close to  street car, bus, and subway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straight from the  shoulder) Does that mean that you want me to  go there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling that he has  offended her) Please don't misunderstand me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you don't want me to go there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a pickle) Now I didn't say that either...  naturally nothing would please me  more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) Then why don't we go? (looking at him) You might be an interesting subject  of study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk toward the elevator as we

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR, ENTRANCE HALL
dialogues.text: In the foreground stands a console on which is a telephon Gaston, Leon's elderly, dignified butler, is answering th phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) No... Count d'Algout is still out.  Yes, as soon as he returns I'll tell  him. Yes... I'll tell him Monsieur  Buljanoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts down the receiver as Leon opens the door with his key. Ninotchka and Leon enter. Ninotchka, during the foll scene, is studying every detail of the apartment with the eye of a technical expert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this what you call the "butler"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes Gaston's hand) Good evening, comrade. (to Leon) This man is horribly old. You should  not make him work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes good care of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks sad. Do you whip him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, though the mere thought makes my  mouth water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the completely  flabbergasted Gaston) The day will come when you will be  free. Go to bed, little father. We  want to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon opens the door to the living room. Ninotchka enters. Just as he is about to follow her, Gaston addresses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) Count d'Algout, there have been  several telephone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR, LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Leon enters the room. Closes the door. Ninotchka is exami the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, may I offer you a drink, or  how about something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I've had all the calories  necessary for today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon feels a little uncertain as to how to approach this  creature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We take off our hat and coat. (he takes her things) We sit down -- we make ourselves  comfortable. We adjust ourselves to  the prospect of a most enjoyable  evening. We look at each other. We  smile. (Ninotchka doesn't  respond) Well... we don't smile. How about  some music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that customary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It helps. It has ever since King  David wooed Bathsheba with the harp.  As I am not so fortunate as to have  my harp at hand, I shall turn on the  radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the observer) I should say this room is eighteen  by twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too big and not too small. What  I'd call the typical room of an  average man. Or shall we say a little  above average. Now if there are any  special aspects you wish to study I  have nothing to conceal. Just look  around. That's my desk. Those are my  books, and here am I. Where shall we  begin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will start with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great. I'm thirty-five years  old. Just over six feet tall. I weigh  a hundred and eighty-two pounds  stripped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is your profession?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeping my body fit, keeping my mind  alert, keeping my landlord appeased.  That's a full-time job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you do for mankind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For mankind not a thing -- for  womankind the record is not quite so  bleak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are something we do not have in  Russia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is why I believe in the future  of my country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I begin to believe in it myself since  I've met you. I still don't know  what to make of it. It confuses me,  it frightens me a little, but it  fascinates me, Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pronounce it incorrectly. Ni- notchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ni-notchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka, do you like me just a  little bit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your general appearance is not  distasteful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me. The whites of your eyes  are clear. Your cornea is excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your cornea is terrific. Tell me --  you're so expert on things -- can it  be that I'm falling in love with  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are bringing in wrong values.  Love is a romantic designation for a  most ordinary biological, or shall  we say chemical, process. A lot of  nonsense is talked and written about  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. What do you use instead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I acknowledge the existence of a  natural impulse common to all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I possibly do to encourage  such an impulse in you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to do a thing.  Chemically we are already quite  sympathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered, and yet  completely intrigued) You're the most improbable creature  I've ever met in my life, Ninotchka,  Ninotchka...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You repeat yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to say it a thousand times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do it, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm at a loss, Ninotchka. You must  forgive me if I appear a little old- fashioned. After all, I'm just a  poor bourgeois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's never too late to change. I  used to belong to the petty  bourgeoisie myself. My father and  mother wanted me to stay and work on  the farm, but I preferred the bayonet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) The bayonet? Did you really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wounded before Warsaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wounded? How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a sergeant in the Third Cavalry  Brigade. Would you like to see my  wound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dumfounded) I'd love to. (she pulls the blouse  off her shoulder and  shows him her scar) Tsk, tsk, tsk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Polish lancer. I was sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Ninotchka. Poor, poor Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (readjusting her blouse) Don't pity me. Pity the Polish lancer.  After all, I'm alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More and more puzzled and fascinated, Leon sits down clos to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of a girl are you, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what you see. A tiny cog in the  great wheel of evolution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the most adorable cog I ever  saw in my life. Ninotchka, Cogitska,  let me confess something. Never did  I dream I could feel like this toward  a sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clock strikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's twelve o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's midnight. One half of Paris is  making love to the other half. Look  at the clock. One hand has met the  other hand. They kiss. Isn't that  wonderful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way a clock works. There's  nothing wonderful about it. You merely  feel you must put yourself in a  romantic mood to add to your  exhilaration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't possibly think of a better  reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's false sentimentality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying desperately  to make her mood  more romantic) You analyze everything out of  existence. You analyze me out of  existence. I won't let you. Love is  not so simple. Ninotchka, Ninotchka,  why do doves bill and coo? Why do  snails, coldest of all creatures,  circle interminably around each other?  Why do moths fly hundreds of miles  to find their mates? Why do flowers  open their petals? Oh, Ninotchka,  Ninotchka, surely you feel some slight  symptom of the divine passion... a  general warmth in the palms of your  hands... a strange heaviness in your  limbs... a burning of the lips that  is not thirst but a thousand times  more tantalizing, more exalting,  than thirst?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses, waiting for the results of his speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are very talkative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is too much for Leon. He takes her into his arms and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that talkative?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that was restful. Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon kisses her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my barbaric Ninotchka. My  impossible, unromantic, statistical...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Glorious, analytical...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone is ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, let it ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But one of your friends may be in  need of you. You must answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon exits out of shot to answer telephone.

dialogues.speaker: AT DESK
dialogues.text: Leon enters, sits down, takes the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello?... Yes... I'm sorry but I  couldn't make it. I ran into a friend  from the army... What?... The deal  is off! Are you crazy, Buljanoff?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is startled by the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A special envoy arrived... What?...  That sounds better. I'll be glad to  see her any time she wants... Oh,  she doesn't want to see me? What do  you know about that? Why?... Well,  I'll get in touch with her myself.  What's her name?... (he takes a pencil  and a piece of paper) ...What?... Yaku... How do you spell  it?... Heavens! those Russian names! (he starts to write  it down) ...I... Oh, Y...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera pulls back and Ninotchka enters the shot. She take pencil from Leon's hand, writes out the name, and leaves  again. At first Leon is not aware of the full significanc of her action. Then it dawns on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Yakushova... Ninotch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last the situation is entirely clear to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) All right. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up and stares at Ninotchka. She is putting on he jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (camera panning with  him as he walks over  to her) Ninotchka...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka, or shall I say Special  Envoy Yakushova...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's forget that we ever met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a better suggestion. Let's  forget that the telephone ever rang.  I never heard that you are  Yakushova... you are Ninotchka... my  Ninotchka...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) I was sent here by my country to  fight you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, fight me, fight me as  much as you want, but fight me  tomorrow morning! There's nothing  sweeter than sharing a secret with a  bitter enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncompromisingly) As a representative of Moscow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight let's not represent anybody  but ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is out of the question. If you  wish to approach me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I want to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then do it through my lawyer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate) Ninotchka, you can't walk out like  this... I'm crazy about you, and I  thought I'd made an impression on  you. You liked the white of my eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka looks at him for a second, then pulls herself  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Ninotchka, I held you in my  arms. You kissed me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kissed the Polish lancer too...  before he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she goes out, we

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: (Note: We have to invent some brief scene to indicate tha three days have gone by. From this we)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler opens the door. Swana enters, her manner showi her complete familiarity with the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Your Highness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count d'Algout is still asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she walks toward  Leon's room) That's all right.

dialogues.speaker: LEON'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The curtains are drawn. The night light is still on. Leon dressing gown over his pajamas, is sound asleep in a big chair. As Swana enters, she sees him with some alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon! What in heaven's name...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anything wrong? Are you ill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me the bed has lost its  best friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just couldn't sleep. I got up and  went back... and then got up again.  These last few days... whew!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, you're taking my business  affairs far too seriously. Much as  I'd love to rob the Bolsheviks of  their filthy money, I won't do it at  the expense of your health.  Particularly as we know we won't get  much. (tenderly) You look so pale... pale but  interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston enters with a breakfast tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your breakfast, monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel like any breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. How can you fight the Reds  and make yourself agreeable to the  Whites if you don't keep up your  strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I draw your bath, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it ice cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in your condition. (to Gaston) Make it tepid, Gaston... tepid and  tender. And lay out his gray suit. (to Leon) Afterwards I'll drive you through  the Bois. Slowly... in Waltz time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blue shirt, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue? Let's offset his mood. Find a  striped one, and brighten it with a  great blaze of tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, Your Highness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston disappears into the bath-dressing room. Swana make Leon sit down and seats herself beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now... here we have two very handsome  soft-boiled eggs. Do you suppose  hens mind what happens to their eggs?  Probably not. They have such unfeeling  eyes. We'll put in a great nugget of  butter, plenty of pepper and salt...  Darling, I haven't seen you for three  livelong days... seventy-two hours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably) Oh, please, Swana! I don't know  whether I'm standing on my head or  my heels. Here you are blaming me  for neglecting you when I'm trying  to concentrate on another woman and  can't get near her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't seen her yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, and believe me I've tried  everything! I must have telephoned  her a hundred times. I've sent her  telegrams, I've sent her flowers...  I asked her to dinner... I offered  her seats for the Opera...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That proletarian! In the old days  we'd have had her flogged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wouldn't have done any good.  Not with her. (forgetting himself) She's the most incredible creature  I've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just told me you hadn't seen  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... er... I caught a glimpse of  her when she walked through the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine the carpets of a self- respecting Parisian hotel dirtied by  the boots of a muzhik! What does she  look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bad? (Leon nods) Old or young?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timeless. When she comes into a room  you'd think that the Bolsheviks had  taken over Paris. She wears her cheap  miserable blouse as though it were  the latest model by Schiaparelli.  What a woman! What a woman! There is  a Russian snowstorm in each of her  eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw all that in one glimpse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) Darling, if we're going to get  anywhere someone has to keep his  eyes open! (he walks over to the  bathroom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, darling, soak in your beautiful  pine bath and let Gaston shave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon exits into the bathroom. As he does so a bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer. After a slight pause she herself goes answer the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT -- ENTRANCE HALL -- LEON'S APARTMENT, shootin toward the door. Swana goes to the door and opens it. The Three Russians s outside. Seeing Swana, they are a little intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swana suspects that for the first time she is being confr by representatives of the Soviet government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to talk to Count d'Algout.  My name is Kopalski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... you are the three gentlemen  from Moscow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icily) You may wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRCASE HALL
dialogues.text: The Three Russians, very impressed, stand looking at the  door which has just been closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine! The niece of the Czar opening  the door for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once in Petersburg I was driving  down the Nevsky Prospect in my cart  and Her Highness in her troika swept  down from the opposite direction,  and when I couldn't make way quick  enough she spat in my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look here, Buljanoff. You never  were in Petersburg, you never owned  a cart, and she never spat in your  face. Who are you trying to impress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment the door is opened by Leon in his bathrobe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Leon and the Three Russians enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's new?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Leon, Leonitchka, she is not going  to negotiate! She is going to fight  that injunction. She's going to make  a precedent of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says she won't be intimidated by  parasites. She called the Duchess a  blood-sucking aristocrat and a  blackmailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) What did she say about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment's  consideration) I think she covered you with the  parasites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon is disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Leonitchka! What she said about  us...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they might believe her in Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean they might -- they  will!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't blame you, Leon, but when  we came from Russia we believed in  simplicity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We avoided luxury and extravagance  and today... well, if you were to  offer us a glass of champagne, we  wouldn't say no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon is so engrossed in his thoughts that he overlooks th hint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, boys, I'd like to help you but  what can I do? Yesterday I waited  six hours in the lobby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't leave her room! She has  been locked in for the last two days  with lawyers and law books!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then make an appointment  with her so I can see her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't... but you are so ingenious,  Leon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found your way to us and we  weren't easy to reach, were we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't we put up a strong resistance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must help us, Leon... if you  don't win her over we're on our way  to Siberia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or it might be the firing squad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or we can't go back to Russia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An idea dawns on Iranoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kopalski and Buljanoff seize on the same idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! We could stay with Leon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon, how would you like to have  three lifelong friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, boys... don't forget Russia is  your mother country. Three sons  walking out all at once... that's  too much for any mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if your mother turns against  you, you have to look for someone to  adopt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swana's voice comes from the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon! Just a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon goes back to the other room. LEON'S BEDROOM -- CLOSE SHOT, shooting toward the door of the living room. Swana stands putting on her gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving, dear. I'm lunching at  Fouquet's if you can make it, and...  Leon, remember, a man should think  it over twice before he decides to  become a mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him lightly and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: DESK
dialogues.text: It is piled deep with law books and papers. Ninotchka sit at it, conferring with two Lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertainly) I seem to remember some additional  injunctive provision dealing with  the property of foreigners residing  in France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with the precision  of a machine) You are referring to paragraph 59b,  section 25f of the Civil Code.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lawyers exchange a glance of surprise at her knowledg One of them takes up one of the law books and as he start to look up the case, Ninotchka speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page eight hundred twenty-four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again the Lawyers exchange a glance of astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do not fail to read the three  footnotes. While you are studying it  I will eat. (She picks up the  telephone) Food please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rakonin is answering the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Room service... Just a moment please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He beckons to someone out of the scene. Leon enters the s and takes the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an assumed French  accent -- into phone) Room service speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Send me a plate of raw carrots and  beets, beets predominating on a ratio  of sixty-forty... What? There is a  strike in the kitchen? Good! Will  you assure the strikers of my hearty  sympathy in their cause. I hope they  will not weaken in their demands and  tell them to put no dressing  whatsoever on my vegetables... What?  You won't serve me either? Now look  here, Comrade, I think it is a fine  idea to let the capitalists go without  luncheon but when you keep food away  from me you're weakening the people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) So! You want to make a strike breaker  out of me! I am surprised at you,  Comrade! Is it too much for the  workers of the world to ask you to  walk around the corner for lunch?  All I can say to you is take your  hammer and sickle and get out of  that Royal Suite!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the telephone with a triumphant smile.

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY OF THE HOTEL CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Ninotchka emerges from the elevator and starts toward the street. As she passes the showcase of the millinery shop  again, she stops and looks at the same hat. Again she sha her head sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tsk, tsk, tsk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks toward the street, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi is parked at the curb. Ninotchka comes from the ho and goes to the taxi.

dialogues.speaker: NINOTCHKA AND TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: The Driver puts his hand on the handle of his cab's door  expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where to, madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you recommend a restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's Pruniers if you care  for seafood. If you want to lunch in  the Bois, there's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Where do you eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At PГЁre Mathieu's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a place for workmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight blocks down in the Rue de  Poivrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door of his cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and starts away in the direction he has indicat The Driver looks after her astounded. The CAMERA PANS from her to the car which stands behind t taxi. It is Leon's smart roadster. Leon sits at the wheel He too is looking after Ninotchka, astonished. He gets ou of his car and starts in the direction she has taken. As does so, we

dialogues.speaker: PARIS STREET
dialogues.text: PГЁre Mathieu's is a workman's restaurant set a few steps below the level of the sidewalk. A few typical French wor are going in for lunch. Ninotchka enters the scene, looks around for a second, then goes in too.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR
dialogues.text: It is a pleasantly simple place crowded with workmen sitt at lunch. An electric piano is playing. PГЁre Mathieu, gr all his guests like a typical restaurateur, sees Ninotchk enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, madame. Are you alone? By  the window perhaps? (He leads the way) Or a nice little corner table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will do. (She sits down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this is the first time you  have been to my little place. Your  face is new to me. Now, what shall  it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raw carrots and beets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified) Oh, madame! This is a restaurant,  not a meadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her a slate on which the menu is written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is what we are offering today.  Please make your choice. I am sure  you will find something to tempt  your appetite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Ninotchka stares in the direction of the door.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Leon has just entered. The CAMERA follows him as he makes his way casually in Ninotchka's direction affecting not t see her. He seats himself at the table directly opposite  Ninotchka and pretends to be overwhelmed with surprise as sees her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, hello! It certainly is a small  world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ninotchka) Well, madame? Shall we start with  soup? Fish soup today. I got up at  five to fish them from the Seine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling over to PГЁre  Mathieu) Crayfish soup for me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Leon) Very well, monsieur. (back to Ninotchka) Then, may I suggest an omelet with  mushrooms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring me something simple. I never  think about food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified) But, madame! If you don't think about  food what do you think about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The future of the common people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sagely) That also is a question of food,  madame. I'll bring you a nice little  lunch Г  la PГЁre Mathieu. (he exits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon leans toward Ninotchka with mock humility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me for addressing you but you  insulted him, you know that. You  hurt his feelings. It was just like  telling a musician you don't like  music. That good old man believes in  food as you believe in Karl Marx.  You can't go around hurting people,  Comrade Yakushova, but maybe you can  make it up to him. Do you know how? (He changes to the  chair at his table  which is closest to  her table) By eating everything with relish, by  drinking everything with gusto, by  having a good time for the first  time in your natural life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like your following me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't follow you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how did you get here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always eat here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a place for workmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laying it on thick) But my dear child, I am most at home  among working men. I hate the places  where you circulate -- the Hotel  Clarence... This is my natural  element. After all, what are any of  us? Workingmen! At least, those of  us who are worth our salt. Hyah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves off scene to a truckman.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKMAN
dialogues.text: He is in the middle of an enormous gulp of food. He regis surprise, winks at his companion, and then, deciding to h a drunk, waves back energetically at Leon in greeting.

dialogues.speaker: LEON AND NINOTCHKA
dialogues.text: Leon has been so successful with the truckman he tries it another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hyah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another truckman responds with equal exuberance.

dialogues.speaker: RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: Leon, intoxicated with his success, waves to the whole ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hyah, fellows!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets a wonderful response from all. They realize that swell drunk is among them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (boastfully) They are all my friends. They're a  swell bunch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PГЁre Mathieu enters the shot and serves a plate of soup Leon and one to Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying his bluff on  PГЁre Mathieu) Ah, my friend! I'm happy to see you  again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm always glad to meet a new  customer, and I hope this first visit  will not be your last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits out of shot. Ninotchka, her suspicion confirmed, looks at Leon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just an old man. His memory is getting  weak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you after?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must one always be after something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your tactics are useless. My name is  neither Buljanoff, Iranoff, nor  Kopalski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ninotchka, who wants to talk  business. If you win the suit, fine.  If we win the suit, better. You do  me an injustice. (He moves over to her  table, leaving the  soup at his table) When we went to my apartment did I  have the slightest idea that you had  any connection with this deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have now, and I know now  that you are a man who employs  business methods which in Russia  would be punished by death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death! Death! Always so glum! What  about life, Ninotchka! Do Russians  never think of life? Of the moment  in which we are living? The only  moment we really have? Don't take it  all so seriously, Ninotchka. Nothing  is worth it. Please... relax... I  beg you, Sergeant... smile!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astonished) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you smile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At anything. At the whole ludicrous  spectacle of life. At people being  pompous and taking themselves  seriously and exaggerating their own  importance. If you can't find anything  else to laugh at you can laugh at  you and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we are an odd couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you should go back to your table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't leave you. I won't. Not  yet. Not until I've made you laugh...  at least once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To get rid of him Ninotchka emits a joyless sound which  approximates a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! Ha! Now go back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a laugh! I mean a laugh  from the heart. Now let's see. I'm  going to tell you a funny story.  Just a moment... I've got it! Well,  it seems there were a couple of  Frenchmen who went to America...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On which boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrown off by her  methodical thinking) Well, er... let's drop it. I don't  think you would care for that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like Scotch stories?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have never heard one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Scotchmen met on the street...  and I don't know the name of the  street and it really doesn't matter.  Well, anyway, one's name was McIntosh  and the other's was McGillicuddy.  McIntosh says to McGillicuddy, "Hello,  Mr. McGillicuddy," and McGillicuddy  says to McIntosh, "Hello, Mr.  McIntosh," and then McIntosh says to  McGillicuddy, "How is Mrs.  McGillicuddy?" and then McGillicuddy  says to McIntosh, "How is Mrs.  McIntosh?"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish they had never met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disarmed) So do I. (after a little pause) Now, here's a great one... Ha! Ha!  Ha! (he looks at Ninotchka  and her expression  stops him) Well, maybe it's not so good. Let's  forget it! How's this? Two men are  looking at the moon. One says to the  other, "Is it true that a lot of  people live on the moon?" "Yes, it  is," says the other, "five hundred  million." "Whew!" replies the first,  "they must get pretty crowded when  it's half moon!" Ha! Ha! Ha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no response from Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to get sore) I suppose you don't think that's  funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seemed funny to me when I first  heard it. Maybe the trouble isn't  with the joke. Maybe it's with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you haven't any sense of humor.  Well, I'll give you one more chance!  Now listen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and speaks in a threatening voice audible to t entire room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I heard this joke for the first  time I laughed myself sick. Here  goes! A man comes into a restaurant  and sits down and says, "Waiter! Get  me a cup of coffee without cream."  After five minutes the waiter comes  back and says, "I'm sorry, sir, we're  all out of cream, can it be without  milk?"

dialogues.speaker: GROUP OF SEVERAL WORKMEN
dialogues.text: They have overheard the story and all burst into laughter

dialogues.speaker: NINOTCHKA AND LEON
dialogues.text: Ninotchka continues to eat her soup without a shadow of a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) Not funny, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't think that's funny? It  is funny! Everyone else thinks so!  Maybe you didn't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (threateningly) I'll tell you that joke again. A man  comes into a restaurant. Did you get  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down at the table and says  to the waiter... Did you get that  too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, so far it isn't funny, but  wait. He says to the waiter, "Waiter!  Bring me a cup of coffee." So the  waiter comes back five minutes later  and says, "I'm sorry, sir, we have  no coffee."... (he realizes he has  made a mistake) Wait a minute... wait a minute...  I'm all mixed up... (he starts over again) A man comes in a restaurant, he sits  down, he calls the waiter and he  says, "Waiter! Get me a cup of coffee  without cream," and five minutes  later the waiter comes back and says,  "I'm sorry, sir, we have no cream,  can it be a glass of milk!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and goes over to his table furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! You have no sense of humor! That  settles it! You have no sense of  humor! None! No humor!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his excitement he leans on the shaky table. It topples forward. Simultaneously his feet shoot from under him and sits violently on the floor, the contents of the table  crashing about him, hot soup in his face. A terrific roar of laughter arises; the whole restaurant rocking with laughter. For a split second Ninotchka makes an effort to control t irresistible impulse to laugh but loses the battle and he roars with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly) What's funny about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka's laughter is uncontrollable. After a moment Leon gets up and sits next to her. As he d himself with his napkin he sees the humor of the situatio and starts to howl with laughter too. The ice is broken a last! On their mutual wild hilarity, we

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: A conference is in session -- Ninotchka, her two Lawyers, and the Three Russians. Ninotchka sits at the desk, leani back in the chair, looking into space, and apparently wei every point which is brought up. One of the lawyers is re from a document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) In addition to the arguments above  enumerated for lifting this  injunction, we wish to cite the  decision of the High Court of Paris,  rendered in the case of Princess  Marishka against the Government of  Montenegro on the fifth day of August,  1897. Comparing the facts in that  case with our present set of facts  we feel that the Treaty between the  Republic of France and the U.S.S.R.  should prevail over all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Ninotchka laughs. Everyone looks at her astonish Ninotchka gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, gentlemen. The other day  I heard such a funny story... (she laughs again) It still makes me laugh. It is very  funny. (a little embarrassed) I am sorry. Oh yes... about this  injunction...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very businesslike) The hearing is set for the twentieth  of this month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not thinking of the  injunction) That's two weeks from Thursday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did our utmost to have it set  ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her attitude  completely different  from her former  business conferences) I know, gentlemen, but it is in the  hands of the Court. We're helpless,  aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It is unfortunate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's nothing we can do about  it. Why get excited?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Three Russians as well as the Lawyers are puzzled. The Russians exchange hopeful glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll leave these papers here for  your further consideration. Au revoir,  madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Au revoir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lawyers leave. Left alone with the Russians, Ninotchka is unable to conc her happiness entirely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it means another two weeks in  Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with exaggerated  efficiency) Too bad we have to waste all that  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I acted on your suggestion and got  in touch with the Power and Light  authorities. Whenever you want to  visit their plants they are open to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little bit dreamily) Oh yes, Power and Light. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something else which I know  will appeal to you. A visit to the  Paris sewers. They tell me it is  extremely instructive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?... Why don't you get a haircut,  Buljanoff? You all look so wintry,  Comrades. And why do we always keep  the windows closed? (she opens the window) Isn't it amazing, at home there's  still snow and ice and here... Look  at the birds. I always felt a little  hurt that our swallows deserted us  in the winter for capitalistic  countries. Now I know why. We have  the high ideal but they have the  climate... well, Comrades, I don't  think I need you any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there is anything we can do for  you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not a thing. Would you like to  go out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Comrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you any money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Russians stammer a negative answer. Smiling benevolently, Ninotchka goes to the table, takes  several bills from her handbag, and goes back, extending fifty-franc bill to Kopalski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here are fifty francs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overwhelmed) Thank you, Comrade, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring me forty-five back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terribly disappointed) Naturally, Comrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Three Russians leave. Ninotchka waits a moment. Then  hurries to the door and turns the key. Camera follows her she goes into the bedroom. She proceeds to the door leadi to the corridor and turns its key. She goes to the table takes a little key from her handbag, goes to the bureau a unlocks the drawer, opens it, and, just as she is about t take out something, her eye falls on the night table, whe she sees the picture of Lenin which she brought with her  from Moscow. She walks over to it and turns its face agai the wall, then goes back to the bureau and takes from the drawer the very hat which twice aroused her disapproval w it was displayed in the millinery shop in the lobby. She moves over to the large mirror, puts the hat on her h is uncertain whether it is right side to fore, and change it. She looks at herself, aghast at seeing a complete  stranger. She sits down, still staring in the mirror, the leans forward and rests her chin on her hand. As she sits studying the new Ninotchka suspiciously, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is evening. Leon is walking nervously up and down. Gas is puttering over the drink table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (consulting his watch) What time have you, Gaston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight forty-two, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it is eight forty-two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem to be a bit nervous, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you will forgive me, ever since  you met that Bolshevik lady I've  noticed a distinct change in you,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (complacently) Have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decidedly. Yesterday I was greatly  amazed when I came from the market  and found that you had made your  bed, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Gaston, I was happier all day  long. I felt I'd contributed  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, if you should do it again,  which I hope you won't, please  remember the order. Counterpane,  blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, there's something poetic about  the simple processes of labor.  Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet,  sheet... it should be set to music!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I add, sir, that it was with  great amazement that I found a copy  of Karl Marx's Capital on your night  table. That is a socialistic volume  which I refuse to so much as dust,  sir. I view with alarm, sir, the  influence over you of this Bolshevik  lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't follow you, Gaston, isn't it  about time that you realized the  unfairness of your position? You  being my servant? Wouldn't you like  to stand on an equal footing with  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there any revolt in you?  Sometimes when I order you around  don't you feel like kicking me in  the pants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emphatically) No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're a reactionary! Don't you  look forward to the day when you can  come in here and stand square on  your two feet and say, "Hey, you,  d'Algout! from now on it's going to  be share and share alike"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outraged) Emphatically not, sir. The prospect  terrifies me. Now, don't misunderstand  me, sir, I don't resent your not  paying me for the past two months,  but the thought that I should split  my bank account with you... that you  should take half of my life's  savings... that is really too much  for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bell rings. Gaston starts for the door. With a  gesture Leon stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to bed, little father, go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston leaves through the other door as Leon exits toward the entrance hall.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE HALL
dialogues.text: Leon enters the scene. He opens the door. Outside stands  Ninotchka wearing her new hat timidly as well as a comple new outfit which she has bought, apparently to match the hat. It takes Leon a few seconds to digest her new splend He takes her hand and leads her in, closing the door. He  looks at her again and kisses her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't look too foolish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foolish? If this dress were to walk  down the boulevard all by itself I  would follow it from one end of Paris  to the other, and when I caught up  with it I would say, "Just a moment,  you charming little dress, I want  you to meet Ninotchka... you two  were meant for each other." Ninotchka  feels more comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon leads her into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: They both enter. Ninotchka pauses a second and looks arou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember this room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been here before. I wonder  whom you're thinking of. Oh, I know,  a girl with a map, figuring out each  step, worrying about north and south.  Today... now this might shock you...  I went up to a taxi and said "Eight  Rue du Bois"... and here I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see? Life can be so simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For twelve francs, seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
