dialogues.text: Twelve seventy-five from the Clarence?  The son-of-a-gun made a detour!... (charmingly) But he got you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment the clock starts to strike. They both look toward it.

dialogues.speaker: CLOCK
dialogues.text: The hands register nine o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: LEON AND NINOTCHKA
dialogues.text: Leon wants to take her in his arms. She resists a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reprimanding him) It's nine o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's when one half of Paris says  to the other half, "What are your  plans for this evening, madame?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting more and  more in the spirit  of her change of  appearance) Well, first I should like to take  off my hat and jacket. (Leon takes them) Then could we have some music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wonderful idea! Radio or records?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not radio. Let's have music that's  just for ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon turns on the victrola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great feeling  and sincerity) I'll play it softly because I have  things to tell you about which I  can't shout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks back to Ninotchka, who by now is seated in an  armchair. He sits on the arm of the chair. He tries to ma a declaration of his love. He stammers several words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my darling... I... we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is no use. In a sudden outburst of emotion he takes he in his arms and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they come out of  the kiss) You see I couldn't shout that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great feeling) Leon, you know the jokes you told me  a few days ago? I wake up in the  middle of the night and laugh at  them. Now, Leon that's wrong. I know  they're not funny, they're silly.  They're stupid. And still... I  laugh... and when I look at Buljanoff  and Iranoff and Kopalski I know they  are scoundrels and I should hate  them -- then I realize who made them  like that, and instead of sending my  report to Moscow I tear it up and go  down and buy a ridiculous hat... and  if this keeps on... am I too  talkative?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (radiantly) No... go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon, I want to tell you something  which I thought I never would say,  which I thought nobody ever should  say, because I thought it didn't  exist... and, Leon... I can't say  it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss again. As the kiss ends they look at each other for a second. Ninotchka gets up and goes toward the desk, sits in the d chair, opens her handbag, which lies there, and takes fro it a little mirror and a lipstick. Before she uses it she looks at Leon with guilty happiness. Leon looks at her wi great tenderness and walks over to the desk and stands lo at her as she makes up her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a gesture for a sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as she is finished, Ninotchka slips the mirror an lipstick back into her handbag and, as she does so, glanc at the top of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon, I would like to ask you  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything, Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't want to answer, you  needn't. But if you do, you must  tell me the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise... I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously) Did you make any change in this room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was here before I noticed a  photograph of a woman on the desk in  a wide silver frame. I thought what  a waste of silver. That's all that  interested me then. Now I would like  to know... what happened to the woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon too is completely serious by now. For answer he quie opens the drawer of the desk. Ninotchka looks in and take from the drawer the photograph. As she looks at it she ri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duchess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon nods gravely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the picture) She is very attractive. She has great  elegance. (she looks back at  Leon) She's what you call a woman of the  world, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a little pause) Ninotchka, I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose she is very entertaining...  It must be lots of fun to be with  her, so witty, so glamorous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka, you're jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka nods sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great feeling) Leon, don't ever ask me for a picture  of myself... I couldn't bear the  thought of being shut up in a  drawer... I couldn't breathe, I  couldn't stand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he takes her in his arms, we

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Duchess Swana enters with a party consisting of General  Savitzky and five other smartly dressed people of the wor The Headwaiter hurries to greet Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Your Highness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Louis. You seem to be  very crowded tonight. Can you manage  a table near the floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, Your Highness, this way  please... Count d'Algout made the  reservation this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Count d'Algout...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is only a small table but it will  be no trouble to put in some extra  chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swana has grasped the situation by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's another party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In order to save the situation one of the ladies makes a  suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we go some other place?  It's so crowded here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted at her  luck) No, no! This is glory! At last I'm  going to have a look at that female  Bolshevik. Can you give us another  table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only one in the rear, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's perfect!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera moves with the group as the Headwaiter leads it to a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Leon's bringing the Bolshevik  you told us about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it divine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have missed this for the  world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very gay, in  anticipation of a  triumph) Now, we must be very discreet. If  she sucks her soup and drinks out of  her finger bowl, I don't want anyone  to laugh. (everybody in the  party giggles) We must not embarrass little Leon.  He is going through enough for my  sake. We mustn't add insult to injury

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now they have reached the table in the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this satisfactory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit down. The Headwaiter bends over General Savitzky an elderly Russian aristocrat, who sits next to Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it to be dinner, monsieur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possibly later. We'll just start  with champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the party) I'm only afraid that the doorman may  spoil our fun. If only he lets her  in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swana laughs and everyone joins in her laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Highness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, General Savitzky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to know all the White  Russian exiles in Paris are keeping  their fingers crossed about the  jewels. They are very interested in  the case. Swana suspects her  countrymen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they indeed? Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hope the settlement will bring  you a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, please... if you hear any  rumors that I am a charitable person,  will you please kill them at their  source?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she is lighting a cigarette a guest suddenly looks tow the entrance and sees Leon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! There's Leon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyfully Swana looks toward the entrance, as does everyon else at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes! Where? There! Oh! How  exciting!

dialogues.speaker: LEON AT THE ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Suddenly, through the door of the cloakroom comes Ninotch radiant in a beautiful evening gown.

dialogues.speaker: SWANA'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Swana's expression freezes as she sees Ninotchka. The res of the guests stare in an embarrassed silence, save for o bird-brained little guest, named Marianne, who feels it h mission to save the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A neighbor nudges her warningly. Swana withers her with a glance and rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we dance, General Savitzky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swana and the General leave for the dance floor. The gues who has nudged her turns to Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you make such a remark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swana isn't stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I say? I just said "isn't  she something?" I didn't say something  what.

dialogues.speaker: LEON'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Leon and Ninotchka are seated and a Waiter stands by them presenting a bottle of champagne to Leon for his approval

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Waiter) Is it dry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ninotchka) Is that right or do you prefer it  sweet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know. The closest I ever  came to champagne was in a newsreel.  The wife of some president was  throwing it at a battleship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always good luck to launch  something with champagne; a  battleship... or an evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now the Waiter is filling their glasses. Ninotchka lif her glass and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny to look back. I was brought  up on goat's milk, I had a ration of  vodka in the army, and now champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaily) From goats to grapes. That's drinking  in the right direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka takes her first sip of champagne. Leon drinks a watches her. The first sip proves a painful surprise.  Ninotchka's face is that of a child who has been fed a ba medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh... um... oh... (slowly the delight  of champagne dawns  on her and her face  breaks into a smile) It's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drinks the whole glass at once. Leon looks at her in  amused surprise. He drinks too. The Waiter fills their gl again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what I read I thought champagne  was a strong drink. It's very  delicate. Do people ever get drunk  on this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There have been cases... but the  headache the next morning is worth  while -- if you drink it with the  right toast. (he raises his glass  again fondly) To us, Ninotchka!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They clink glasses and drink again, looking at each other LONG SHOT OF THE TABLE, including part of the dance floor As Leon and Ninotchka lift their glasses again, Swana and General Savitzky start to dance by the table. Swana stops pretending complete astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Leon! What a surprise! You of  all people! How are you, my dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon gets up. Ninotchka watches the scene tensely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Hello, Swana. How do you do, General  Savitzky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Leon) You're looking magnificent, Leon... (to General Savitzky) ...isn't he, General Savitzky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon knows that Swana wants to embarrass him but is  embarrassed nevertheless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your new dress suit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell you Benson and Benson  were the tailors for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently) Yes, Swana, you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a dream of beauty. He never  takes my word for anything, but I  was right, wasn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forcing an  introduction) Am I interrupting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. Your Highness, may I  present Madame Yakushova?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And General Savitzky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've some wonderful news for you,  Leon. It's about Punchy... do you  mind if I sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing that he  cannot prevent it) No... please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swana sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to General Savitzky) General, would you mind making my  excuses at our table? I'll be back  in a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Leon, we can be proud of our  Punchy. He had a triumph at the dog  show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the following speech, Ninotchka's expression does change. She knows exactly the game Swana is playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) He won another blue ribbon and bit  the judge. Ha! ha! ha! I bought him  the cutest sweater as a reward. You  should see him strut down the street  in it. He looks like a little  boulevardier. (to Ninotchka) You see, Count d'Algout gave me Punchy  for my birthday. (to Leon) You must have searched weeks before  you found anything as divine as  Punchy, didn't you, Leon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fed up with Swana's  tactics) Months, Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ninotchka) Poor Madame Yakushova... here we are  talking in mysteries.... I'm sure  you wonder what it's all about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dry and direct) Not at all.... I understand perfectly,  Count d'Algout gave you a dog. You  made it very clear, madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear me... I must be losing my  finesse. If I'm not careful I'll be  understood by everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acutely uncomfortable) There's a charming crowd here tonight,  isn't there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going, Leon... (she rises, as does  Leon, delighted to  get rid of her) but before I leave I must compliment  you on your gown, Madame Yakushova.  Is that what they're wearing in Moscow  this year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, last year, madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swana sits again, as does Leon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it amazing! One gets a wrong  impression of the new Russia. (cynically) It must be charming. I'm glad  conditions are so improved. I assume  this is what the factory workers  wear at their dances?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. You see, it would have been  embarrassing for people of my sort  to wear low-cut gowns in the old  Russia. The lashes of the Cossacks  across our backs were not very  becoming, and you know how vain women  are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right about the  Cossacks. We made an unpardonable  mistake when we let them use their  knouts. They had such reliable guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon has grown more and more uncomfortable as the two lad fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you do me a favor? Stop talking  about the good old days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very wise suggestion, Leon. I'm  afraid madame and I will never agree. (she plays her trump  card) The only thing we have in common is  our lawsuit and that will be decided  next week. I understand everything  will be over by Thursday. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka and Leon realize the malice and yet the truth o her words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, madame, it will all be  over by Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubbing it in) It is unfortunate that you have so  few more days in Paris. (she turns to Leon) Be sure and redouble your efforts so  that madame can take some pleasant  memories when she returns to Moscow. (she rises, Leon rising  too) Good night. (Ninotchka nods without  answering. To Leon) Good night, Leon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) Good night, Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swana leaves the table. Leon sits again. The mood of the has been changed by the problem of their separation, whic has been brought before them. They sit in silence for a  moment. Ninotchka speaks first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I think I need a glass of  champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon fills their glasses. They drink. Then Leon takes  Ninotchka's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to break the  mood) Quickly, please... tell me one of  your funny stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A funny story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never finished the one about the  two Scotchmen with the names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there were two Scotchmen. One  was named McIntosh and one was named  McGillicuddy. They met on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, darling. I'll tell you another  story, a much better one. (with deep sincerity) The only thing that will be over on  Thursday is the lawsuit. There will  be no Thursday for us. Not next week  or any week. We won't let it happen.  I'll tear it out of the calendar. Is  that a good story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touched) Wonderful -- if one could believe  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifting her glass) To the loveliest story I ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drink. The orchestra starts a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (afraid of where the  conversation may  lead) Shall we dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both start toward the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: LEON AND NINOTCHKA, DANCING A WALTZ
dialogues.text: At the second turn Ninotchka starts to feel the effect of the champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tipsily) Oo! Darling! Something is the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just made that trip from goats  to grapes a little too fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, everything is so wonderful! It's  getting farther and farther away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Don't worry. Everything will be  all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the gayest mood, Ninotchka addresses the crowd on the  dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comrades! Comrades!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Darling, darling... please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must talk to my brothers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh! Shhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shush me. I am People! I want  to make a speech. I want to overthrow  the Duchess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon starts to lead her off the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, darling, you can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comrades! Good people of France!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Ninotchka... please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all Duchesses here...  thousands of Duchesses... and I am  going to tell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now they have almost reached the powder room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite right... yes, yes, yes, but  first you're going in that door and  you're going to take a little spirits  of ammonia and lie down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) No speech?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as though he were  addressing a little  child) No speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, my little Leonitchka!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I adore you, Ninotchua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka goes unsteadily into the powder room. Leon wipe his forehead in relief and goes to the bar, followed by t CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Give me a double brandy.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR OF THE POWDER ROOM
dialogues.text: A group of four to six women come out whispering excitedl about something which must have happened within. CAMERA goes with them as they go to the Manager of the  restaurant and crowd about him and whisper what has happe

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: The bartender gives Leon his double brandy and Leon tosse it off. The Manager comes into the shot and addresses Leo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very excitedly) I'm very sorry, Count d'Algout, it  is most embarrassing, but the lady  you brought with you tonight is  spreading communistic propaganda in  the powder room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon stares at him for a second, then turns to the barten

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me another double brandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kind of propaganda is bad  anywhere, but inciting the attendants  of a powder room to go on strike....  Well, if she succeeds the consequences  will be disastrous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has been asked to leave the powder  room but without success. We would  appreciate if you would see to it  yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified) You want me to go in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir, but I must insist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Manager bows and walks away. Leon gulps down the seco double brandy. The CAMERA follows him as he proceeds towa the powder room like a hero going into battle. Just as he about to enter, a very dignified elderly lady comes out, surprised at his attempted entrance, and glares at him. L loses his courage and FOLLOWED BY THE CAMERA goes back to the bar to strengthen it with some of the Dutch variety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completely exhausted --  to the bartender) Make it a triple brandy. As we

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Rakonin, the waiter, opens the door. Ninotchka and Leon,  both very tipsy by now, enter the room. Leon is carrying bottle of champagne in a napkin. As he passes the waiter speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rakonin) All right... you can tell the  Duchess... you can tell everybody...  they know anyhow... it doesn't make  any difference... now get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rakonin, who seems very interested in the situation, clos the door. Leon goes to Ninotchka. Both sit on a couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving close to him) Don't tell them where we're going,  sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nobody will find us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka is lyrically tight. Through her there shines a  great happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we going to build our little  house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... a little white house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not white, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, we'll make it red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, don't let's have it any color...  no color... just a house house...  let's form our own party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right: Lovers of the world unite!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) And we won't stretch up our arms...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and we won't clench our fist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tenderly) Our salute will be a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... a kiss... salute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sinks into his arms and they kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still in his arms) I am so happy. No one can be so happy  without being punished. I will be  punished and I should be punished. (she gets up) I want to confess, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... it's the Russian soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her gaiety mixed  with sadness) Everyone wants to confess and if  they don't confess they make them  confess. I am a traitor. When I kissed  you I betrayed the Russian ideal.  Leon, I should be stood up against  the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sympathetically) Would that make you any happier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much happier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still carrying the champagne bottle, Leon leads her to th end of the room and stands her against the wall. He takes the napkin from the champagne bottle and puts it over her eyes. The CAMERA moves with him as he goes away from  Ninotchka, and as he walks he starts to open the champagn The cork pops. CLOSE SHOT -- NINOTCHKA, as she sinks gently into a chair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) I have paid the penalty. Now let's  have some music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's turn on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radio! What is radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little box that you buy on  the installment plan and before you  tune it in they tell you they have a  new model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) Oh yes, yes. It has a little knob  that turns... a little knob... it  must be somewhere around here...  yes... here... I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confusedly Ninotchka starts looking for something, repeat "a little knob... a little knob." Followed by Leon she go toward the safe, opens the concealing door, and both are  delighted as they see the safe's dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphantly) Here it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon nods approval and starts to turn the dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shall we get? The news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no news. We don't want to know  what's happening in the world. We  want to be left alone, don't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sweetheart... all by ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remembering vaguely) Well, then we turn twice to the right  and stop at seven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon follows her instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a little pause,  sadly) It's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it has to warm up... you have  to give it a chance... just like  people... like you and me... first  you wanted to fight me and now we  belong to the same party... salute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her in his arms and again they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as though she were  in heaven) Now twice to the left and stop at  seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon again follows her instructions. INTERIOR -- SAFE, shooting toward the door. Leon opens the door and both look into the safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) No music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also disappointed) No, no music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through her fog, Ninotchka becomes aware of the case  containing the jewels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) There it is... Thursday... you can't  rip it out of the week....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helpfully) But I can throw it out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (philosophically) It wouldn't be fair to the man in  the street. (she pushes back the  lid) There they are... they are terrible  things, those jewels....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...they are the tears of Old Russia...  see that stone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cried that one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Czar Peter gave it to his wife,  Catherine the Great. For it he sold  ten thousand serfs in the market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, darling, don't get impatient,  wait until we are married. You know  that worthless butler of mine...  that reactionary? Some day when I  come home to you I may say, "Darling,  I drove Gaston to the market and  look what I got from him!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the case of jewels he takes a beautiful diadem and h it in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the economist now) First ten thousand serfs... now just  Gaston. It is very encouraging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon takes her by the hand and leads her from the safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, sweetheart. Let me put it on  you. You will teach these jewels.  For the first time they will learn  how they can look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They belong to the people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a ceremonial voice) I give them back to the people... (as formal and steady  as possible under  the conditions he  puts the diadem on  her head) I make you Ninotchka the Great...  Duchess of the People!... Grand  Duchess of the People!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka falls in with the spirit of this imaginary  coronation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the wish of the masses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is their wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Leon... thank you, masses. (in a low voice) Can I make a speech now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka turns to an imaginary assemblage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comrades! People of the world! The  revolution is on the march... I  know... wars will wash over us...  bombs will fall... all civilization  will crumble... but not yet, please...  wait, wait... what's the hurry? (mixing reality with  fantasy) Let us be happy... give us our  moment.... (turning to Leon) We are happy, aren't we, Leon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fondly) Yes, sweetheart. (he holds her in his  arms)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her voice getting  dimmer and dimmer) So happy and so tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She falls asleep in his arms. Leon gathers her up and car her into the bedroom, the diadem still on her head.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Leon carries Ninotchka to the bed, puts her down on it. S is now sleeping soundly. He kisses her once more and then turns, the CAMERA PANNING with him, and starts toward the door to the corridor and exits. As he closes the door wit an uncertain hand, it slams. CLOSE SHOT -- NINOTCHKA, as she lies on the bed On the night table beside her is a photograph of the ster faced Lenin. The crash of the slamming door awakens Ninot for a moment. Completely content and happy, she turns aro and sees the disapproving face of the photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (charmingly) Smile, little father, smile.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPH OF LENIN
dialogues.text: The photograph of Lenin starts to smile in approval, as w

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN ON
dialogues.text: IN THE FOREGROUND a clock shows that it is a quarter to  twelve.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM OF THE ROYAL SUITE
dialogues.text: It is taken from an ANGLE which includes the door. The li are still on, the curtains drawn, the empty champagne bot and glasses litter the room. We hear the buzzer of the  corridor door ring several times without an answer. CAMERA moves through the door into the bedroom, never  disclosing the bed. The lights in the bedroom are still  lighted also and the curtains drawn. CAMERA stops on the  door from the bedroom to the corridor. The buzzer rings.  Apparently the caller has moved from the living-room door the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: THE BED
dialogues.text: Ninotchka is lying on the bed, still in her evening dress The diadem is no longer on her head, but no special empha is laid on that detail in the camera angle. We hear the s of the buzzer ringing again and again. Ninotchka half wak and calls out something which sounds like "come in" witho being fully aware of what she is doing.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The door is opened from the outside by a maid, who lets i the Duchess Swana, dressed in a smart morning outfit. Swa looks around, surprised and amused at the state of the ro She walks over to the bed where lies Ninotchka, still not enough awake to face reality. Swana is delighted to have  surprised Ninotchka in this condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ironically) Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awakening gradually) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is tomorrow morning... tomorrow  noon, to be exact. I hope you will  forgive me. I know it's extremely  cruel to waken anyone at such an  hour. Don't you recognize me? I am  the Duchess Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now Ninotchka is awake. She gets up and realizes to he acute embarrassment the condition in which Swana has foun her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how you feel, my dear. The  morning after always does look grim  if you happen to be wearing last  night's dress. Don't be embarrassed  by my presence, though. You couldn't  have found anybody more sympathetic  to your condition. I remember once  in Petrograd when I felt exactly as  you do. I had to bow from a balcony  to the crowd. My dear, the masses  have no understanding of the feelings  of a lady before noon. Don't you  find that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During Swana's speech Ninotchka has found herself complet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we can cut your visit short.  Leon is not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, my dear! I didn't  come here with any such suspicion.  How ridiculous! (with a glance toward  the living room) Nor did I come here to pick up his  hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- LEON'S HAT, shot through the bedroom door i the living room where it lies on the table.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: By the bed stand Ninotchka and Swana. Swana starts toward the living room, Ninotchka following her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she reaches the  threshold) How stale last night's gaiety looks!  It has the taste of a dead cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were encouraged to come here  by our meeting last night I am afraid  you misunderstood my attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, you were quite rude  enough. (during the following  speech, she draws  the curtains and  opens the windows) Do you mind if I let in a little  fresh air and sunshine? I'm sure it  will make you feel better and I want  you to be at your very best. In full  possession of your faculties, at  least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regaining her usual  firmness) Please come to the point. What is it  you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just dropped in to have a little  heart-to-heart talk with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have nothing to discuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there you are completely wrong.  If we sit down for a little chat,  I'm sure we won't run out of  conversation and what's more it won't  be dull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame, what is it you people always  say, regardless of what you mean...  "I am delighted to have you here"? I  have not reached that stage of  civilization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right... I grow on people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must ask you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave? That's exactly what I came  here to ask you to do. Leave! I don't  mean this hotel and I don't mean  Paris... I mean France. There's a  plane for Moscow at five-forty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Madame, if you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I have already made  reservations. It's perfect flying  weather. They assure me there's a  fine tail wind which will sweep you  back to Moscow in no time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still not  understanding) If this is meant to be a joke it is  not funny. Or do you still think  you're issuing orders from your palace  in Petrograd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka's words for the first time sting Swana out of h apparently superficial attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) My palace in Petrograd... yes, you  took that away from me. You took  away my czar, my country, my people,  everything I had... (with emphasis) but nothing more -- I warn you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) People cannot be taken away, madame,  neither a hundred and sixty million  nor one. Not if you have their love.  You hadn't. That's why you're not in  Russia any longer, and that's why  you came here this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very interesting, my dear, but  couldn't you write all that from  Moscow? A dissertation on love on  Soviet stationery -- would be an  amusing paradox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not enough to be witty, madame.  People grow tired of being  entertained. You made that mistake  before. Problems were never solved  by bowing from a balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, you don't know how impressive  I could be. Did you ever see me in  my regalia with my diadem and all my  jewels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The word diadem startles Ninotchka. She starts to remembe the night before, and she looks toward the safe. INSERT OF THE DOOR OF THE SAFE, which is closed by now.

dialogues.speaker: NINOTCHKA AND SWANA
dialogues.text: Ninotchka stares in the direction of the safe as Swana  chatters on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't deny we gave the people  their money's worth -- almost --  eight tumbling Romanoffs -- eight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately) I must insist that you leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not before you agree to use those  reservations to Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case I can only say good-by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abruptly she walks toward the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: NINOTCHKA
dialogues.text: She enters the small room connecting the living room and  bedroom and closes the door to the living room. She walks into the bedroom toward the bed and glances at it. The di is not there. After going back into the anteroom, she ope the outer door of the safe and pulls on the inner door. I has not been properly closed and opens at once. The safe empty. Ninotchka stands staring in frozen horror for a mo then rushes to the telephone by the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the telephone) Г‰lysГ©e 2763.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- NINOTCHKA AT THE TELEPHONE, waiting for her  connection In the background the door to the living room is opened b Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing in the door) I wouldn't waken Leon. After last  night I would say not before three  o'clock at the earliest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to go, madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, Leon can't help you. He  doesn't know anything about the  jewels... I give you my word... I  swear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka hangs up the receiver and stares at Swana. She  walks toward her. LIVING ROOM, SHOOTING INTO THE BEDROOM. In the foreground Swana, in the background Ninotchka, who is hurrying towar her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were very careless with our  precious jewels, my dear. They're  too expensive a toy for two children  to play with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Fortunately last night  a very trustworthy friend kept his  eyes open. Perhaps he overstepped  his function as a waiter but he  fulfilled his duty as a Russian. (she draws back the  fur scarf she is  wearing, revealing a  diamond star, one of  the jewels we have  seen) I just put this on for sentiment.  The rest are absolutely safe. I assure  you. But if you feel like notifying  the police...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leave me no choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't it be rather embarrassing for  a Soviet Envoy to disclose the  circumstances under which she lost  them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will have to face the consequences,  but so will you. Don't forget they  will ask how you got them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very simple to answer. They  were given to me by my mother. They  were given to her by her mother, in  fact they're mine, you cannot steal  what belongs to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She proceeds into the living room, followed by Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They always belonged to the Russian  people. They were paid for with their  sweat, their blood, their lives and  you will give them back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphantly) I told you we had plenty to talk  about. Shall we sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very matter-of-fact) Now, let's free ourselves from  emotionalism and try to solve the  problem in a practical way. Our  situation has changed considerably.  Before I had only a claim to the  jewels. Now I have the jewels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words moral ideas have no  weight with you... all right, then  let's deal with legal facts. You  know that France has recognized the  Soviet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under Soviet law the jewels belong  to the State. France is going to  uphold that ownership.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lawyer agrees with you. He says  France will uphold it in every court,  but I will drag you through every  court, don't forget that. And when I  say it will take two years I am, as  always, conservative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't those two years in court be  expensive for you? I know that money  was no object as long as you could  squeeze it from the pockets of the  people, but now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may run out of money, but you have  already run out of bread. Two years  is a long time for your comrades to  wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. You have calculated in terms  of hunger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just wanted to be absolutely  impartial. Both of us are faced with  two rather uncomfortable years. We  can condense these two years to two  minutes if you want to accept my  proposition. Ninotchka now realizes  what she is after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am willing to hand over the jewels  and sign the necessary papers if you  take that five-forty plane to Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) That's not the way to win him back...  not Leon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I know Leon quite as well as  you... possibly a little better.  Leave that worry to me. Five-forty  leaves you time enough to close the  deal with Monsieur Mercier, but  naturally you'll be too busy for any  farewells. I'll see to it that  everything is done in the most  expeditious manner and I will also  see you to the airport. That's my  proposition, Comrade Yakushova.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka knows herself to be faced with an inevitable  decision. For a moment she cannot answer. The telephone r Ninotchka takes the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into telephone) Yes... (it is Leon) Oh hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much as she wants to talk to him she hesitates in the pre of Swana. Swana realizes the situation, gets up, and walk over to the window, where she stands looking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Leon... (forcing herself to  be gay so that he  will not suspect  anything) ... no, you didn't waken me... I am  fine, thank you.... Yes, it was...  marvelous.... What?... for luncheon?  I'm afraid I can't. I am going to be  very busy... (looking for excuses) well, I have a lot of things to attend  to today.... What?... Well to tell  you the truth I am a little tired  and I would like to rest... (she forces herself  to laugh) you may be right... perhaps it is  the champagne.... For dinner?... Of  course... seven o'clock here?... (realizing that she  will be gone by then) seven o'clock is all right....  Where?... That will be lovely....  Yes... (there is a knock on  the door) Come in. (into the telephone) Yes?... (looking toward the  door she sees  something which makes  her stop the  conversation) Just a moment... (she puts the receiver  on the table and  walks toward the  door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANTEROOM BETWEEN LIVING ROOM AND CORRIDOR, shooting towar the living room. In the background we see Swana standing the window. Ninotchka comes into the anteroom, closes the door in order to shut off Swana's view. Camera pans with  Ninotchka as she walks toward the hall door where the bel is putting down a big flower basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to bellboy) You can leave it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bellboy exits. Ninotchka looks at the basket of flowe for a moment, then takes the envelope which is attached t the handle. She opens it and reads the enclosed letter. I must be a love note, for her eyes grow wet. She turns to last page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...and sweetheart, I have kept my first promise. I sent  poor old Gaston to the market this morning and if you wil look deep into the flowers you will see what I got for  him...."

dialogues.speaker: NINOTCHKA
dialogues.text: She puts her hand in the basket and takes out a bottle of milk.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOTTLE
dialogues.text: On the label we see a picture of a goat.

dialogues.speaker: NINOTCHKA
dialogues.text: She smiles sadly and goes to the telephone, which is on t console in the anteroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into telephone) Operator, will you switch the call  please?... Hello?... Darling, your  present just arrived.... It's very  silly and very wonderful... thank  you... No, I won't forget... seven  o'clock.... (with great tenderness) Good-by, my darling.... What?...  Oh... (softly) salute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts down the receiver. Camera pans with her as she g to the door of the living room. She opens the door and go in. Swana turns from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry to have kept you waiting,  madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shooting from a HIGH ANGLE. We hear the SOUND of an airpl just taking off. Camera pulls back so that Swana seems to photographed from the airplane. Finally the SHOT disclose the whole airport and Swana disappearing into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE HALL
dialogues.text: Swana's maid is opening the door for Swana, who enters in the highest spirits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Your Highness. (hesitantly) Madame, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't find my glove. All right,  you're forgiven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Your Highness. Count  d'Algout is waiting. He's been here  some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swana inspects herself briefly in the hall mirror, procee into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Leon is pacing up and down. Swana enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon, darling, how nice! Have you  ordered tea or a cocktail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I act stupidly last night? Should  I apologize?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the one who should apologize. I  should have talked to you before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this, by any chance, going to be  a confession?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, my little Volga boatman.  Have you forgotten our First  Commandment: Never Complain -- Never  Explain. It has worked so often and  so perfectly, don't let's break the  rule. And please don't look so guilty,  otherwise I'll...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time, Swana -- just this once --  I must ask you to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you hate the obvious but do  you mind if, at this moment, I'm not  in the least subtle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutal frankness, if you insist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a hundred ways to approach  it, but I feel it can best be said  in one simple phrase. I'm in love,  Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I thought it was something  serious! How could you frighten me  so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be serious, Swana. Not long  ago I'd have considered such a  statement rather juvenile and rather  middle class. Now I can say it without  stammering, without a blush. I'm in  love, Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it over and over again, Leon.  Words are a wonderful safety valve,  and that's what you need -- because  you know it's impossible, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to be simple again, Swana,  and you may find it shockingly banal.  I've thought it over and I'm willing  to take all the consequences, even  if it means a complete readjustment  of my way of living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon! This has the ugly sound of  regeneration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that's what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same old trouble, Leon. You're  always late. Whether you're taking  me to the Opera or calling for me at  a beauty shop, you're never on time.  And now, when it's a question of  your reform -- late again. (she glances at her  wrist watch) By about five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, Swana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knowing the efficiency of the French  Air Service I think I can guarantee  that Madame Yakushova has already  taken off for Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has done what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gone, Leon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you expect me to believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swana picks up the receiver of the telephone and holds it out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the telephone. If you call  the hotel you will find that you  have no seven o'clock appointment.

dialogues.speaker: THE MOSCOW PLANE
dialogues.text: It is flying past the Eiffel Tower.

dialogues.speaker: AIRPLANE WINDOW
dialogues.text: Behind the window we see Ninotchka looking at Paris for t last time. Camera moves over to the next window and we se Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski also giving Paris a sad  farewell look. ANOTHER VIEW OF PARIS, from the air. The mist has closed by now so that only the top of the Eiffel Tower is visibl above it. CLOSE-UP -- NINOTCHKA, looking down on the Tower INTERIOR, Airplane -- Ninotchka, Buljanoff, Iranoff, and  Kopalski Ninotchka turns from the window and leans against the bac of her chair. The Russians follow her example. There is a moment of silence and sadness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine, for once in our lives we  were in Paris and we never went to  the Eiffel Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tell me it has a wonderful  restaurant on the second floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While you eat, you look at the view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is trying to overcome all sentimentality, but as the  following speech progresses she cannot escape the persona implication involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is an amazing piece of  engineering. Still the most remarkable  iron structure in the world. Leading  to the top there is a staircase of  over a thousand steps... but an  elevator is included in the price of  admission.

dialogues.speaker: HERALD DU MATIN
dialogues.text: Camera zooms down on a headline of an article. Mercier buys priceless russian jewels. Russian commission has left for moscow.

dialogues.speaker: STREET IN PARIS
dialogues.text: Camera follows Leon as he walks excitedly and nervously a the boulevard. He turns into a Russian Intouriste Bureau, one of the travel bureaus maintained by the Soviet govern in foreign countries to supply information regarding trav give visas, etc.

dialogues.speaker: INTOURISTE BUREAU
dialogues.text: It is a typical travel bureau. Behind the counter are  attendants and some people getting information and pamphl Leon enters, looks around, and sees a door which says "Vi and Passport Department." He enters.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR, VISA ROOM
dialogues.text: It is a room smaller than the previous one. Behind the co stands a typical Bolshevik Official. In front of the coun is an elderly English lady. Leon takes his place behind h nervous at having to wait. The Official stamps the Englis lady's passport and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, everything is in order. I hope  you will enjoy your trip to Russia,  madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Oh, by the way, I've heard  so many rumors about laundry  conditions in Russia. Is it advisable  to take one's own towels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not, madame. That's only  capitalistic propaganda. We change  the towel every week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves. Leon moves up to the Official.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment the telephone rings. The Official takes th receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes... Comrade Cazabine? No, I'm  sorry... he hasn't been with us for  six months. He was called back to  Russia and was investigated. You can  get further details from his widow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the receiver. Leon, thinking of Ninotchka, is horrified by this statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, I am very interested in  what you just said -- you mean when  an envoy goes back to Russia -- if  they don't like what he has done  they put him out of the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not always... look at me... I've  been back twice. (he knocks on wood)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his alarm growing) Here's my passport.... Please give  me a visa. I have to leave for Russia  immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading passport) Count Leon d'Algout... a count!... a  nobleman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hold that against me... please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should an aristocrat want to go  to Russia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no privacy in Russia. This  whole thing seems very suspicious.  What's the real reason? If you ever  want to get into Russia, take my  advice... confess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismayed) Confess what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sympathetic to the former  Czaristic government -- the White  Russians?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary -- I don't want to  have anything to do with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe in our cause?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon, feeling that he has to go to the rescue of his girl whips up an enormous enthusiasm for the cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... I think it's great! Everyone  works -- everyone contributes --  that's what I want to do -- work! I  make my own bed -- you can call up  my butler! I don't believe in the  right of the individual. I like the  Bolshevik ideal -- everyone being  the same. You just like me -- me  just like you -- I use your comb --  you use my toothbrush -- oh, it's a  great life.... Please... give me  that visa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment Swana enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Leon darling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suavely) After our talk last night  I took it for granted that you would  drop in here this morning. Knowing  how difficult it is to get into Soviet  Russia, I thought I might be of some  assistance to you. (to the Official) May I introduce myself? I am the  Duchess Swana of Russia... another  Russia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Official gasps in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, please, Swana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Official) Count d'Algout was for several years  my personal representative and if it  is necessary to sign any affidavit  for him I'll be delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) That does it, Swana. (he leads her toward  the door) Now you mustn't miss your appointment  with your hair-dresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping at the door) Just in case they don't give you  your visa to Russia I want you to  know that I have signed a contract  for my memoirs and rented a lovely  little chГўteau in the Touraine, and  if you feel the need of a change...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Swana. You are very  gracious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His words are unmistakably a final dismissal. She walks o Leon looks after her for a second, then goes back to the  Official. He tries to laugh off the incident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must have her little joke. (the Official responds  with a stony look) You're not going to take that  seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Grand Duchess Swana... active in  the White Russian movement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I have no connection  with her any longer... I swear I  haven't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you had!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I want to be absolutely frank  with you. I have no business in  Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see a friend of mine... a  very dear friend.... It's a personal  matter which has nothing to do with  politics or social philosophies....  It's a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's love which drags you to  Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No visa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting for his  point) I must get into that country of yours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. No visa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more aggressively) That's impossible! Nobody has the  right.... You can't do that!... If  you don't give me that visa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ironically) You're going to force us... huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (growing violent) Now look here... you advertise all  over the world that you want people  to go into your country and when  someone tries to get in, you keep  him out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I take a chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know you don't want to blow  up a factory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for... why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or a tunnel or a bridge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suspicions... nothing but  suspicions!... That's the trouble  with you! If you don't let me in  I'll stand in front of this office  of yours and warn people to keep  away from Russia!... I'll picket  your whole country....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Official laughs in a superior way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll boycott you, that's what I'm  going to do!... No more vodka... no  more caviar... no more Tchaikovsky...  no more borscht.... Wait a minute, I  know something better than that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Official leans forward sarcastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a knock-out blow, Leon sends him to the floor, then, leaning over the counter, he shouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can tell the Kremlin that's  just the beginning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides out. The Official's head emerges from the counter. As he adjus his bruised jaw, he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No visa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing Shot of Russia -- First of May -- Stock Shot May Day Parade on the Red Square

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March, march, march! Comrades of the  World, never has there been such a  May Day parade as this! Already for  four hours the pavements of Moscow  have resounded to the tread of a  million boots! Thousands of gun- carriages have thundered past.  Thousands of tanks, combined with  our mighty air force, have  demonstrated to a belligerent neighbor  that we are ready and invincible!  Now past me marches the great army  of our civilians! Men and women of  all ages. All servants of the State  united in one thought and ideal.  Group of Several Units Marching

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Workmen, soldiers, tanks, airplanes, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Column of Women, dressed in typical Russian May Day parad fashion, marching and saluting. The CAMERA NARROWS DOWN t CLOSE SHOT OF Ninotchka marching with the others. All her individuality is gone. She is one of many, a cog in the  Russian machine. With a stern expression she is looking  straight ahead when suddenly something attracts her atten and she glances to one side. A Column of Male Workers is coming in the opposite direct Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski are recognizable among t CLOSE SHOT -- BULJANOFF, IRANOFF, AND KOPALSKI MARCHING. three are already pretty exhausted from the long march.  Kopalski sees Ninotchka. He whispers it to the others. Th three look toward Ninotchka and lift their shoulders with gesture which says, "Look where we are now." CLOSE SHOT -- NINOTCHKA, answering them with a sad smile. After they have passed she stares straight forward again  with the same stern expression.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRCASE IN NINOTCHKA'S TENEMENT HOUSE
dialogues.text: It is an overcrowded house. People are walking up and dow stairs, standing grouped in front of the various apartmen children are sliding down the banisters and playing games under the feet of the adults. Ninotchka trudges upstairs wearily. Camera pans with her she goes into an apartment which is divided into several apartments. Finally she opens the door of her own room an goes in.

dialogues.speaker: NINOTCHKA'S ROOM
dialogues.text: It is a comparatively small room, which she shares with t other girls. As she enters only one girl is present. It i Anna, a cello player, who sits on the edge of her bed  practicing on her cello. Apparently Ninotchka has not adj herself completely to the Moscow which she once thought s great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the opera starts an hour later  tonight on account of the parade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the following scene Anna puts her cello in its cas and gets ready to go to her job. Ninotchka starts to arra the table in the center of the floor for a party of four. Out of her cupboard she takes very primitive-looking dish a flower pot, glasses, and a kind of shawl which serves a tablecloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you march?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is apparently not a fanatical believer in the Bolshe regime and takes a cynical and humorous attitude toward i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't let me. I am in disgrace.  Last week at the performance of Carmen  I played a sour note. The conductor  got so excited he yelled, "There's  sabotage in the string section!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad... you missed an inspiring  day, Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... my heart is sad... but my  feet are happy. When all the tanks  and guns were roaring over the Red  Square I sat here all by myself and  played a Beethoven sonata. Not bad  at all. (she has noticed  Ninotchka's  preparations) Are you expecting someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few friends... just a little dinner  party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you serving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An omelet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) An omelet! Aren't you living a little  above your ration?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've saved up two eggs and  each of my friends is bringing his  own so we'll manage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just goes to prove the theory of  our State. If you stand alone it  means a boiled egg but if you're  true to the collective spirit and  stick together you've got an omelet. (devilishly) That reminds me... have you heard  the latest they're telling about the  Kremlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment a door to one of the adjoining rooms opens and Gurganov, a middle-aged man with a sour stool-pigeon  expression, walks quietly through the room to another doo taking in the girls with one sly glance and giving the  impression that not only his eyes but his ears are open.  Anna breaks off her remark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) I'll tell you later. (after Gurganov has  disappeared into the  other room she  continues) That Gurganov, you never know whether  he's on his way to the washroom or  the Secret Police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be more careful, Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you too, Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed) About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever since you have been back from  Paris...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't talked to anyone about  Paris. I haven't said a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just it. It makes people feel  queer. I dont' want you to get in  any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should. I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks over to her cupboard and takes out a piece of  lingerie and comes back to Ninotchka with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I passed through the laundry  yard today I saw all the women huddled  around this so I brought it up here.  Things like this create a bad feeling.  First they didn't know whose it was.  Then they saw the Paris label and  did it start a commotion! Some said  it's what we all ought to wear and  others said it's like hanging foreign  ideas on our clothesline. It  undermines our whole cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aware of the pettiness  which surrounds her) I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how it is today... all you  have to do is wear a pair of silk  stockings and they suspect you of  counter-revolution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Anna. I'll dry it up here  when I wash it next. I should hate  to see our country endangered by my  underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confidentially) Ninotchka, you know I am your friend,  you can trust me.... Did you bring  back anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka suddenly is transported to Paris in her memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with feeling) No, I left everything in Paris. I  just happened to be wearing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me... what else did you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enjoying the thought) Well, a hat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was very silly.... I would be  ashamed to wear it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As beautiful as that? What else?  Come, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An evening gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Evening gown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dress you wear in the evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you wear in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get up you put on a negligee,  and then you change to a morning  frock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to tell me you wear a  different dress for different times  of the day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Ninotchka, you're exaggerating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my dear, it is true. That's how  they live in the other world. Here  we dress to have our bodies covered...  to keep warm....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sometimes they're not completely  covered but... they don't freeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fingering the piece  of lingerie) They must have wonderful materials  to make a thing like this so soft...  something you don't even see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel it, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Ninotchka, I wouldn't bring this up  if we weren't such good friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Anna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I told you that Pavlov and  I are going to get married when he  comes back from the maneuvers. Would  it be asking too much...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for the honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have it for good. It is my  wedding present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is for a moment speechless over this generous gift. embraces and kisses Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka! Ninotchka!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses her again, takes her cello, and starts to leav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I going to play that cadenza  tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna exits, closing the door. Ninotchka is left alone. He thoughts are still in the other world, obviously with Leo Mechanically she looks over the table to see if everythin is all right, then she walks over to the radio (a primiti little machine). As she turns the knob she smiles again  reminiscently. As she does, the blare of a Russian speech brings her back to reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Individuals? Yes, as atoms in the  cosmos of Soviet Russia. Family?  Yes. One great family of one hundred  and sixty million, struggling,  fighting, victorious Russian  proletarians. Thus shall we pursue  our way into the future, fists  clenched, hearts encased in steel  armed against bourgeois sentimentality  and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly she turns the knob and again there is a burst of  Russian oratory.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND VOICE ON RADIO
dialogues.text: ...From the Exploiters for the Toilers. We are going full steam ahead through industrialization toward socialism. L us put the Union of Socialistic Soviet Republics into an  automobile and the muzhik into a tractor, and then let th capitalists try to keep up with us! The same thing happen for a third time.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD VOICE ON RADIO
dialogues.text: ...and thirty million peasants, eighty-five per cent of t population owned three hundred forty-three million four  hundred and sixty-nine thousand acres of land, sixty-five per cent of the total area. And one hundred and fifty tho nobles possessed thirty-five per cent of the country's na wealth! Ninotchka turns off the radio. She closes her eyes for a  moment and with a sad smile murmurs to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment the door opens, and Buljanoff, Iranoff, an Kopalski enter. There follow warm greetings between Ninot and the Three Russians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka! Ninotchka!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of silence follows. The four look at each other people do who share a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great warmth) How are you, you three scoundrels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly) Well, we're back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sourly) You know what they say -- there's  nothing like home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right... and we might as well  face it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying not to say  what she feels) Come, now, you must not talk that  way.... You have to adjust  yourselves.... We must be brave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brave... that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's be happy that we're all alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's something we owe to  Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you hadn't given Commissar Razinin  such a wonderful report about us,  who knows what would have happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's forget everything except  that we're together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (falling in with her  attempt) It's a real Paris reunion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you close your eyes and listen to  our voices we might be in Paris.
