dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not close our eyes. There are  many good things to see here too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynically) I think I need my glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reprimanding him  quietly) A little more tact... look how nicely  she's fixed the table -- all for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a loud voice,  trying to make up  for his faux pas) How nicely you've fixed the table,  Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a lovely room you have here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many families live here with  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only myself and two other girls. One  is a cello player in the opera and  the other a street-car conductor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) Just three people in a room this  size? Whew!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inspecting the room) And your own gas cooker? That's  marvelous! (forgetting himself) Naturally it's not the Royal Suite...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh! Once and for all, we're in  Moscow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking over to the  window) Yes, there's no doubt of that... (sarcastically) Just look out of the window and there  it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's great! Think what it was a  few years ago and what it is now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iranoff and Buljanoff have joined them at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's right... (under his breath) anyhow let's talk ourselves into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just see how happy the people look...  from here....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you blame them?... at least the  May Day parade is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's another thing... it's spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same spring we had in Paris.  Just as good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even the swallows are back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that's the same swallow we saw  in Paris!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is, Ninotchka! It is! He must  have been in Paris! You can see it  in his whole attitude! He just picked  up a crumb of our black bread, shook  his head, and dropped it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you asked him why he left France  I bet he couldn't name one good  reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be a swallow! Right now I  would be sitting in front of the  CafГ© de Paris picking up flakes of  French pastry that would melt in my  bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, comrades... there is something  better in life than crumbs of French  pastry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the realist) Yes, a good piece of apfel strudel....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will get that... we'll get  everything... maybe a little bit  later but we'll get it... We must be  patient... Finally we got the spring,  didn't we? We got the swallows, and  you will get your apfel strudel too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (consolingly) And if it is too late for you your  children will eat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking the mood) Let's forget the future... let's  stop being sentimental... let's start  that omelet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. (he takes a little  box out of his pocket) Here's my egg. (he hands it to  Ninotchka)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iranoff unties his egg from his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here's mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands it to Ninotchka. Buljanoff reaches in his pocket and from his expression w see that a catastrophe must have happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comrades... I'm out of the omelet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry... there will be enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Ninotchka, let's make it in  real Parisian style!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group all go to the gas cooker and Ninotchka starts t make the omelet. The others stand around as though they w watching a great event.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's fill it with confitures, des  prunes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...des raisins de MadГЁre, des  framboises... (...with grapes of  Madeira, with  raspberries...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...des petites fraises des bois...  de la crГЁme de Bretagne... (...with small wild  strawberries... with  cream...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so it blows up that big... what  they call an Omelette Surprise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the surprise is there's nothing  in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but if we can't put in all  these wonderful things at least let's  put in some imagination. (he raises his voice) In that one omelet we'll taste the  whole of Paris!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door through which Gurganov disappeared opens and Gur comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing him) Sssh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conversation stops. Gurganov walks quietly through th room, again observing everything. He goes out at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man like that... all he has to do  is to walk through a room and the  omelet drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a dead silence. All are again aware of the reali which surrounds. They concentrate quietly on the frying p

dialogues.speaker: THE FRYING PAN
dialogues.text: The eggs are gradually taking the shape of an omelet.

dialogues.speaker: A PLATE ON THE TABLE
dialogues.text: Only the last scraps of the omelet are on it. Buljanoff's hand comes in with a big piece of bread with which he sop up every fragment that is left.

dialogues.speaker: NINOTCHKA'S ROOM
dialogues.text: The curtains are drawn and the lamp lighted. All four are sitting around the table, in the center of which is a sam In front of each of them is a glass of tea. One of the  Russians is playing a balalaika and all are singing gaily "Paris." Ninotchka is enjoying their companionship. After a little while the door to the corridor opens and Ninotchka's othe roommate, the street-car conductor, strides in. She is a  squareset, unfriendly woman in uniform. At sight of her one of the Russians nudges Ninotchka, mak the gesture of ringing up a fare, and accompanies it with inquiring look. Ninotchka nods. The Russians change their tune quickly to the "Volga Boatman" in order not to awake animosity. The street-car conductor goes to her bed and starts to ta off her shoes and her coat, then draws the curtain. Durin the following scene we hear the splash of water and the s of gargling. Again Gurganov crosses the room, this time accompanied by his little son. Suddenly the door is opened by Vladimir, a friendly old m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling into the  room) Comrade Yakushova, here, the postman  left a letter for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her a letter and exits.

dialogues.speaker: NINOTCHKA
dialogues.text: She takes the letter, glances at the envelope, and is stu She turns the envelope -- an expression of breathless won comes over her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Ninotchka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Leon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Leon!... How is he?... Come,  tell us... open it... tell us... how  is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka sits in the chair nearest the lamp. All three a looking over her shoulder. Ninotchka hesitates to open th letter, obviously wanting to read it all by herself. Real her feelings, the Three Russians walk to the far end of t room and sit down on a little bench, looking toward Ninot with childlike expectancy. In great anticipation Ninotchk opens the letter. She starts to read it. Suddenly her  expression changes to one of terrific disappointment. She turns the letter over, glances at the second page, then p the letter down on the table. The Russians have followed expression closely. Slowly they walk over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very sympathetic) Bad news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look for yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iranoff picks up the letter. All three look at it. Insert of First Page of Letter, held in Iranoff's hand. I Leon's handwriting we read: "Ninotchka, my darling," The rest of the writing is blocked out, line by line, and across the page is a big stamp which says "Censored."  Iranoff's hand turns the page. The second page is also  censored except for the final words, "Yours, Leon."

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF THE WHOLE GROUP
dialogues.text: Iranoff puts the letter back on the table. They all under and realize that Ninotchka wants to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think it's getting late.  Good night, Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for a wonderful dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka rises and shakes their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great warmth) Good night, my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three start to leave but Buljanoff returns and whispe to Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't censor our memories, can  they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka presses his hand. He walks quietly out with the others. Ninotchka, left alone, sits down. She is heartbroken. Her thoughts are too sad and too far away to be disturbed by snoring which comes from the corner where the street-car  conductor has gone to bed.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: shooting from the inside. Through the window the backgrou of Moscow. It is winter and snow is on the roofs. The CAM PULLS BACK and discloses Razinin sitting at his desk, rea a report with a stern expression.

dialogues.speaker: RAZININ'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Ninotchka enters carrying several folders. She walks to  Razinin's desk and stands waiting for him to recognize he presence. She is a tired, stern girl. Razinin looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Comrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very businesslike) Good morning, Comrade Commissar.  Here is my report on the materials  available for trading in the next  four months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this include the products of  the Far Eastern provinces?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you have finished the whole  investigation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's marvelous.... You must have  worked day and night.... Don't you  ever sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need very little sleep. We must be  extremely careful what goods we take  in exchange. I have already started  a survey of our most urgent needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Comrade, I am afraid you will  have to turn over that work to someone  else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) May I ask why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Comrade, have you heard from  your friends Kopalski, Buljanoff,  and Iranoff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't either, but I've heard  about them. You must realize it was  only on the strength of your Paris  report that I sent them to  Constantinople; without that I never  would have trusted them on a mission  as important as the fur deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask what has happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as our representatives go to  a foreign country they seem to lose  all sense of balance. If I told you  what's going on in Constantinople  right now you wouldn't believe it.  Those three have been sitting there  for six weeks and haven't sold a  piece of fur. (he points to the  folder) This anonymous report was sent me.  They are dragging the good name of  our country through every cafГ© and  night club. Here... (he reads from the  report) "How can the Bolshevik cause gain  respect among the Moslems if your  three representatives, Buljanoff,  Iranoff, and Kopalski, get so drunk  that they throw a carpet out of their  hotel window and complain to the  management that it didn't fly?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka has to suppress a smile of amusement at the ant of her three old friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they shouldn't do such things.  Are you sure this report is correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gives details which couldn't be  invented. Naturally I want to verify  it and that's why I need you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apprehensively) You want me to go to Constantinople?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... leaving immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her one object to  escape the mission) I appreciate the confidence you show  in me, but I must ask you to entrust  someone else with this mission. I  should hate to interrupt my present  work. I am positive that my survey  is more important than finding out  whether three of our comrades have  been drinking some extra glasses of  champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (austerely) That is for me to decide, Comrade  Yakushova.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry, I don't want to overstep  my position -- but please... don't  send me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making a last effort) How can I make myself clear... It is  difficult to express but I'd rather  not go to foreign countries any more.  Please, Comrade... let me stay here...  let me finish my work... I am in the  rhythm of it now... I don't want to  go away. I don't want to be sent  into that foreign atmosphere again.  It throws one out of gear.... Let me  finish my work... I have concentrated  everything in it... Please... don't  make me go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't waste my time, Comrade.  Do your duty. Good-by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT OF CONSTANTINOPLE, on a bright sunlit d if possible with the circling shadow of an airplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- AIRPORT IN CONSTANTINOPLE, shooting from an  airplane angle. A crowd is awaiting the arrival of a plan The CAMERA goes down to a CLOSE SHOT of Buljanoff, Iranof and Kopalski, standing in the crowd. All three are very elegantly and gaily dressed. They are the happiest mood. One of them carries a large bouquet of flowers to greet Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM OF A VERY LUXURIOUS HOTEL SUITE IN CONSTANTIN
dialogues.text: Its style should suggest the locale. Ninotchka enters wit the Three Russians, who are very happy to have her with t again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the room) How do you like it, Ninotchka? Isn't  it wonderful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us... tell us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka protests, but during the whole scene it is evid that behind her protestations there is none of the force conviction she displayed in a similar situation in the Ro Suite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Buljanoff, Iranoff, Kopalski...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, please, Ninotchka, don't start  figuring it out in cows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done it again and I am  responsible. How can you forget  yourselves this way? You were sent  here to make money, not to spend it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buljanoff, she still has those old- fashioned Bolshevik ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is high time you got out of Russia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not knowing what to  do with the three  rascals) I must be stern with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) That's our old Ninotchka!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agreeing with him) Yes, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget, the day will come when  you will have to face Razinin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cockily) Good old Razinin! Is he still alive?  How does he manage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Comrades...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with the happiness  of being free again  in his voice) We are not comrades any more... we  are friends, Ninotchka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine, we don't have to whisper  any longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can say whatever we want. We can  shout... we can complain... Look... (he opens the door  leading to corridor) The service in this hotel is terrible! (he closes the door) See? Nobody comes... nobody pays any  attention. That's freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) No, that's bad management.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it possible to bring you back to  reality for a moment? I must have a  complete report of your negotiations  and a detailed expense account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask for it, Ninotchka. There  is a Turkish proverb which says, "If  something smells bad, why put your  nose in it?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there is a Russian saying: "The  cat who has cream on his whiskers  had better find good excuses."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With our cream situation what it is,  it is Russia which should apologize  to the cats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helplessly) Friends... friends, Buljanoff,  Iranoff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (afraid of being left  out) ...and Kopalski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleadingly) Don't make it difficult for me. This  is no more a pleasure trip for me  than it is for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was our idea when we first came.  All we thought we would get out of  this trip was a Turkish bath, but...  we learned better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka, we are in the magic East,  the country of Aladdin and His Lamp...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves...  into one single hour you can crowd a  thousand and one nights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you have to do is say "open  sesame."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how I can get you out  of it this time. How will it end?  What will happen to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intimately) Shall we tell her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) Ninotchka, I hope you'll be our guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have opened a restaurant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we have a wonderful electric sign:  "Dine With Buljanof, Iranoff, and  Kopalski."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you are deserting Russia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing the song of  freedom) Don't call it desertion. Our little  restaurant... that is our Russia...  the Russia of borscht, the Russia of  beef Stroganoff, blinis with sour  cream...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the Russia of piroshki... people  will eat and love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not only serving good food,  we are serving our country... we are  making friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completely bewildered) Who gave you this idea? What is  responsible for all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a gleam in his  eye) There's something in Constantinople...  something irresistible....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it is in the air... it may come  around the corner as you walk down  the street....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it may step out of a bazaar... it  may wait for you in a corridor... it  may hide in the shadow of a  minaret....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the  balcony) Right now it's on the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka looks toward the balcony and is dumbfounded as sees Leon standing there smiling at her. He walks quietly toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking longingly at  Ninotchka) They wouldn't let me in so I had to  get you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still taken aback) So -- you're behind all this. I should  have known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon takes her hand and kisses it. The Three Russians exc glances. The CAMERA PANS WITH THEM --leaving Ninotchka an Leon as Russians walk discreetly out of the room and clos the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to keep me away from you! It  couldn't be done. Naturally I couldn't  go on forever punching passport  officials in the nose -- but I found  a way, didn't I? Darling, I had to  see you. I wrote and wrote but all  my letters came back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one I got they wouldn't let me  read. (carried away by  emotion) It began, "Ninotchka, my darling,"  and ended, "Yours, Leon."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great feeling  and sincerity) I won't tell you what came between...  I'll prove it. It will take a long  time, Ninotchka... at least a  lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninotchka is aware that she is facing a decision. She kno what she wants but still tries to evade a definite answer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Leon, I am only here for a few  days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't stay with me, I'll have  to continue my fight. I'll travel  wherever Russian commissions are.  I'll turn them all into Buljanoffs,  Iranoffs, and Kopalskis. The world  will be crowded with Russian  restaurants. I'll depopulate Russia.  Once you saved your country by going  back. This time you can save it by  staying here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when it is a choice between my  personal interest and the good of my  country, how can I waver? No one  shall say Ninotchka was a bad Russian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon takes her in his arms, they kiss as we
